column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Wikinews : What part or period of the history of the World Wide Web did you enjoy most ?
#Text=Which were the most exciting times ?
#Text=Robert Cailliau : Enjoy ?
#Text=Only afterwards , except the first conference .
#Text=There was a euphoric atmosphere that I have seldom experienced .
#Text=And because I started it myself , it was extremely satisfying .
#Text=The most exciting period was from end 1991 to end 1994 .
#Text=It was the early period where we sensed very clearly where we wanted to go but had to instill that vision in others .
#Text=It lasted until the end of WWW at CERN in December 1994 .
#Text=I cannot relate the whole story here , it is told in detail in the book " How the Web was Born " .
#Text=Wikinews : If you could go back into time and change one thing about the start of the WWW , what would it be ?
#Text=Robert Cailliau : Isambard Kingdom Brunel , one of the greatest engineers of all times , wrote in 1844 at the height of the railway mania :
#Text=Here the whole world is railway mad .
#Text=I am really sick of hearing proposals made .
#Text=I wish it were at an end .
#Text=I prefer engineering very much to projecting , of which I keep as clear as I can ...
#Text=The dreadful scramble in which I am obliged to get through my business is by no means a good sample of the way in which work ought to be done ...

#Text=I wish I could suggest a plan that would greatly diminish the number of projects ; it would suit my interests and those of my clients perfectly if all railway work were stopped for several years to come .
#Text=I thought often of that reflection : we advanced far too fast with far too many developers who ran away in far too many different directions without much thinking .
#Text=I do n't want to be Cartesian here , but it would have been better if we had more time to build on our ideas before letting the beast loose .
#Text=We advanced far too fast with far too many developers who ran away in far too many different directions without much thinking . ...
#Text=Especially the geeks in the U.S. often behaved like cowboys : shoot first , think later .
#Text=— Robert Cailliau
#Text=Especially the geeks in the U.S. often behaved like cowboys : shoot first , think later .
#Text=Features were implemented that looked attractive on first sight but turned out to be incompatible with other ones .
#Text=For example the famous frames , that we still have not got rid of .
#Text=People failed to understand the advantage of separating content from presentation , which we had on the NeXT in some sense .
#Text=Especially graphic artists refused this and that put us back by about five years .
#Text=If a careful study were made it might well show that we lost much more time and effort managing excesses than we would have spent in a more considerate and paced development .
#Text=I often had the impression I was running like mad to escape from drowning in a tsunami .
